Chianna Maria Bono |residence=[[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]], [[California]], [[United States|U.S.]] |website=[http://bono.house.gov/ Congresswoman Mary Bono] }} '''Mary Bono Mack''' (born October 24, 1961) is the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Representative]] for {{ushr|CA|45}}, and previously the 44th, serving since 1998. She is a member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. The district is based in [[Palm Springs, California|Palm Springs]] and includes most of central and eastern [[Riverside County]]. Bono Mack sits on the [[Energy and Commerce Committee]], and is Chairwoman for the Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade. Bono Mack is the only Republican woman in California's congressional delegation. ==Early life== She was born Mary Whitaker in [[Cleveland, Ohio]], but moved to [[South Pasadena, California]], in 1963. She worked her way through the [[University of Southern California]], graduating in 1984 with a Bachelor of Arts in Art History. She was an accomplished [[gymnastics|gymnast]] in her youth. ==Congressional career== [[Image:Mary Bono Mack.jpg|thumb|Earlier photo of Mary Bono, c. 2005]] The 45th had long been a Republican stronghold but has become much more Democratic in recent years; it currently has a [[Cook Partisan Voting Index]] of R+3. While [[Moreno Valley]] and Palm Springs have a slight Democratic tilt, [[Palm Desert]] is strongly conservative. Her district includes the highest percentage of gays and lesbians of any district represented by a Republican.{{cite web | url = http://www.law.ucla.edu/williamsinstitute/publications/SameSexCouplesandGLBpopACS.pdf | title = Same-sex Couples and the Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual Population: New Estimates from the American Community Survey | publisher = The Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation Law and Public Policy, [[UCLA School of Law]] | date = October, 2006 | accessdate = February 15, 2007 }} Bono Mack followed the Republican Party line 89% of the time according to ''[[Congressional Quarterly]]''. In 2004, she received an 84% approval rating from the [[Christian Coalition of America]],[http://www.cc.org/2004scorecard.pdf ]{{dead link|date=September 2010}} but this fell to 33% in 2008.http://www.cc.org/files/3/2008_Scorecard_8_5x11.pdf In 1999, she voted in favor of the Largent Amendment,http://clerk.house.gov/evs/1999/roll346.xml to ban [[adoption by same-sex couples]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.commondreams.org/pressreleases/july99/072999f.htm |title=Human Rights Campaign |publisher=Commondreams.org |date=1999-07-29 |accessdate=2010-09-30}} Bono Mack has, however, voted against the [[Federal Marriage Amendment]] twice. Some of the congresswoman's legislative history includes a bill that calls for country-of-origin labeling for fresh fruits and vegetables, as well as several energy-saving bills to reward companies for utilizing clean burning fuel technologies and increase the energy-efficiency of federal buildings. In 2000, Bono Mack helped pass legislation that established the [[Santa Rosa and San Jacinto Mountains National Monument]] in the [[Palm Springs]] region. The House of Representatives passed her [[Cyber-security_regulation#Proposed_regulation|'''S'''ecurely '''P'''rotect '''Y'''ourself '''A'''gainst '''C'''yber '''T'''respass]] (SPY ACT), which would protect an individualâs personal information on the Web. Also, Bono Mack has sponsored legislation that provides funding for obesity studies and improved nutrition programs nationwide, autism research, and Federal funding under the Ryan White HIV/AIDS Act. [http://bono.house.gov/Biography/] Congresswoman Mary Bono Mack: Biography Bono Mack was a leading proponent of the [[Sonny Bono Copyright Term Extension Act]] of 1998, the so-called Mickey Mouse Law, which extended the terms of copyright. Giving a speech on the floor of Congress in favor of the bill, Bono Mack said:
Actually, Sonny wanted the term of copyright protection to last forever. I am informed by staff that such a change would violate the [[United States Constitution|Constitution]]. ... As you know, there is also [[[Motion Picture Association of America]] president] [[Jack Valenti]]'s proposal for the term to last forever less one day. Perhaps the Committee may look at that next Congress.[http://frwebgate1.access.gpo.gov/cgi-bin/waisgate.cgi?WAISdocID=151115310684+0+0+0&WAISaction=retrieve 144 Congressional Record H9952]{{dead link|date=October 2010}}.
She won her sixth term in 2008 with 58% of the vote,Riverside County Registrar of Voters down slightly from 60.7% in 2006.[http://www.marybono.com/news.php?id=113 Bono Election Day Schedule]{{dead link|date=September 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sos.ca.gov/elections/sov/2006_general/congress.pdf |title=sov_detail_congress.xls |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-09-30}} In December 2010, Bono Mack was one of fifteen Republican House members to vote in favor of repealing the [[United States military]]'s "[[Don't Ask, Don't Tell]]" ban on [[Coming out|openly homosexual]] service members.Chris Geidner, [http://www.metroweekly.com/poliglot/2010/12/breaking-house-passes-dadt-rep.html House Passes DADT Repeal Bill], ''[[Metro Weekly]]'' (December 15, 2010).[http://politics.nytimes.com/congress/votes/111/house/2/638 House Vote 638 - Repeals 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'], ''[[New York Times]]'' (December 15, 2010). Bono Mack has received numerous awards from such organizations as [[Americans for Tax Reform]], [[National Federation of Independent Businesses]], the [[National Association of Manufacturers]], and the [[SunLine Transit Agency]] for her support of alternative fuel technologies. She is also a signer of the Taxpayer Protection Pledge.{{cite web|url=http://www.atr.org/current-taxpayer-protection-pledge-signers-th-a2851 |title=Current Taxpayer Protection Pledge Signers |publisher=Atr.org |date= |accessdate=2010-09-30}} ===Committee assignments=== *'''[[United States House Committee on Energy and Commerce|Committee on Energy and Commerce]]''' **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade|Subcommittee on Commerce, Manufacturing and Trade]] (Chairwoman) **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Communications and Technology|Subcommittee on Communications and Technology]] **[[United States House Energy Subcommittee on Environment and Economy|Subcommittee on Environment and Economy]] *[[Congressional Hispanic Conference]] {associate member} *[[Republican Main Street Partnership]] ===Caucus memberships=== *America Supports You Caucus *Intellectual Property Promotion and Piracy Prevention Caucus (Co-Chair) *[[United States Congressional International Conservation Caucus|International Conservation Caucus]] *Recording Arts and Sciences Caucus (Co-Chair) ==Media coverage== Bono Mack has been the subject of numerous profiles for a wide array of publications and television shows, including ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', ''Capital Style'', ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'', ''[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]]'', ''[[George (magazine)|George]]'', ''[[Good Housekeeping]]'', ''[[Hello Magazine|Hello!]]'', ''[[Ladies' Home Journal]]'', and [[PBS]]. In 1998, Bono Mack was named one of the "Most Fascinating Women of 1998" by ''Ladies' Home Journal'' magazine in conjunction with [[CBS]] Television. She was also selected by the former ''George'' magazine as one of the 20 most fascinating women in politics. In 2008, she was named the "Seventh Hottest Politician in the World" by ''[[Maxim (magazine)|Maxim]].'' ==Personal life== In 1986, Bono Mack married singer and actor [[Sonny Bono]] and moved to Palm Springs. In his biography, ''The Beat Goes On'', Sonny said "When I wrote songs I always knew if I was on to something that was great. I could just tell. I felt that way about being with Mary. I knew it was great." Soon after, Sonny Bono became interested in politics, serving as Mayor of Palm Springs (1988-92) and being elected to Congress (1994). When reflecting about his marriage and family, Sonny said, "I've never been happier. For the first time I feel free to really love someone and to be a great father."Sonny Bono: And the beat goes on Due to Sonny Bono's commitment to [[Scientology]] at the time, Bono Mack took some Scientology courses together with her husband but soon decided it was not for her.{{cite news|title=Proud Mary Bono|work=[[George (magazine)|George Magazine]]|date=August 1999|last=Bardach|first=Ann}} Sonny Bono died in a skiing accident on January 5, 1998. Thereafter Bono Mack won the Republican nomination for the special election to succeed him. She then won in the special election April 7, 1998. She won a full term in November and has been re-elected since. As of 2007, Bono Mack was one of six representatives to be elected to their seats following the deaths of their husbandsâ[[Lindy Boggs]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[Louisiana|LA]]), [[Jo Ann Emerson]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Missouri|MO]]), [[Lois Capps]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[California|CA]]), [[Doris Matsui]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-CA), and [[Sala Burton]] ([[Democratic Party (United States) |D]]-CA). In 2001, Bono Mack married Wyoming businessman Glenn Baxley about 18 months after they met in Mexico. They filed for divorce in 2005.{{cite web|author=The Associated Press |url=http://www.pe.com/localnews/inland/stories/PE_News_Local_D_bonowed17.4d6b542.html |title=Reps. Mary Bono, Connie Mack marry | Inland News | PE.com | Southern California News | News for Inland Southern California |publisher=PE.com |date=2007-12-17 |accessdate=2010-09-30}} On December 15, 2007, Bono Mack married Congressman [[Connie Mack IV]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[Florida|FL]]) in [[Asheville, North Carolina]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,316990,00.html |title=Fox News, GOP House Members Mary Bono and Connie Mack Marry in North Carolina |publisher=Foxnews.com |date=2007-12-16 |accessdate=2010-09-30}} Bono Mack has a son, Chesare Elan Bono (born 1988), and a daughter, Chianna Maria Bono (born 1991), from her marriage to Sonny Bono. She has four stepchildren: Christy Bono, [[Chaz Bono]], Addison Mack, and Connie Mack. In addition to her family, Bono Mack has interests in music and outdoor activities such as hiking and camping. In the April 2008 edition of ''[[Golf Digest|Golf for Women]]'' magazine, she was listed as "one of the 50 most powerful women who play" golf.Golf for Women, April 2008 After attending a lecture by mountaineer-turned-humanitarian [[Greg Mortenson]], Bono Mack worked with him to open doors in [[Washington, D.C.]], to aid his efforts to build schools for girls in the mountainous regions of Pakistan.
